dublin_core.dcvalue: Smokers N 74 who volunteered for a smoking cessation study monitored their daily experiences for up to 6 weeks prior to the quit date Self reports from 7 707 diary records were used to examine the associations among alcohol consumption present in 607 diary records situational factors smoking urge to smoke and subjective consequences of smoking Alcohol use smoking urge and the subjective effects of smoking were context dependent Momentary reports of smoking and alcohol consumption were associated with one another Alcohol use predicted smoking even when contextual factors were covaried Alcohol use was associated with more frequent reports of urge to smoke Alcohol was also associated with more frequent reports that the last cigarette produced a rush buzz was good tasting and reduced the urge However effects for rush buzz and urge reduction were qualified by interactions between alcohol use and the latency since smoking Rush buzz tended to be associated with alcohol use regardless of smoking recency Alcohol was associated with urge reduction only when the cigarette being appraised was smoked more than 15 minutes prior to the diary entry
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T16:59:07Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2008-06-10
Psychology of addictive behaviors : journal of the Society of Psychologists in Addictive Behaviors
Alcohol consumption, smoking urge, and the reinforcing effects of cigarettes: an ecological study.
